Folk epidemiology of [[autism]] refers to the popular beliefs about the [[Causes of autism|origin of autism]].<ref name="1.">{{cite journal|last1=Moore|first1=Alfred|last2=Stilgoe|first2=Jack|title=Experts and Anecdotes|journal=Science, Technology, & Human Values|volume=34|issue=5|year=2009|pages=654–677|issn=0162-2439|doi=10.1177/0162243908329382}}</ref> Without direct knowledge of autism, a rare and complex disease, members of the public are influenced by rumors and misinformation presented in the [[mass media]] and repeated on [[social media]] and the [[internet]].<ref name="1."/><ref name="LewandowskyEcker2012">{{cite journal|last1=Lewandowsky|first1=Stephan|last2=Ecker|first2=Ullrich K. H.|last3=Seifert|first3=Colleen M.|last4=Schwarz|first4=Norbert|last5=Cook|first5=John|title=Misinformation and Its Correction|journal=Psychological Science in the Public Interest|volume=13|issue=3|year=2012|pages=106–131|issn=1529-1006|doi=10.1177/1529100612451018}}</ref> These misinformed beliefs persist even when contradicted by [[scientific evidence]].<ref name="LewandowskyEcker2012"/><ref name="2.">{{cite journal|last1=Sharts-Hopko|first1=Nancy C.|title=Issues in Pediatric Immunization|journal=MCN, The American Journal of Maternal/Child Nursing|volume=34|issue=2|year=2009|pages=80–88|issn=0361-929X|doi=10.1097/01.NMC.0000347300.39714.19}}</ref> Folk epidemiology persists because people seek, receive, and preferentially believe information that is consistent with their existing views;<ref name="LewandowskyEcker2012"/> misjudge the reliability of their sources of information, and are misled by [[anecdotal evidence]];<ref name="1."/><ref name="2."/> and tend not to revise their opinions even when their original sources of information are shown to be wrong.<ref name="LewandowskyEcker2012"/>
The scientific consensus is the MMR vaccine has no link to the development of autism, and that the vaccine's benefits greatly outweigh its risks.<ref name=MMRthefacts>{{cite web |url=http://www.dh.gov.uk/en/Publicationsandstatistics/Publications/PublicationsPolicyAndGuidance/DH_4002972 |accessdate=2007-09-19 |year=2004 |title= MMR The facts |publisher= [[National Health Service|NHS]] Immunisation Information|archiveurl=http://webarchive.nationalarchives.gov.uk/20130107105354/http://www.dh.gov.uk/en/Publicationsandstatistics/Publications/PublicationsPolicyAndGuidance/DH_4002972|archivedate=7 January 2013}}</ref> Folk beliefs that the [[MMR vaccine]] causes autism led to a sharp drop in rates of vaccination in the UK and Ireland after 1998 and corresponding increases in the incidence of vaccine-preventable childhood illnesses, disability, and death.<ref name=McIntyre>{{cite journal |vauthors=McIntyre P, Leask J |title= Improving uptake of MMR vaccine |journal=The BMJ |volume=336 |issue=7647 |pages=729–30 |year=2008 |pmid=18309963 |pmc= 2287215 |doi=10.1136/bmj.39503.508484.80}}</ref><ref name=Pepys>{{cite journal |journal=Clinical Medicine |year=2007 |volume=7 |issue=6 |pages=562–78 |title= Science and serendipity |author= Pepys MB |pmid=18193704 |doi=10.7861/clinmedicine.7-6-562}}</ref>
== MMR vaccine and autism == In 1998 [[Andrew Wakefield]] published a fraudulent article in a ''The Lancet'', a prominent British medical journal, claiming that the MMR [[vaccines caused autism]].<ref name="3."/> Although the article was later retracted, the idea that vaccines cause autism became a major news story.<ref name=Goldacre-2008>{{cite news |title= The MMR hoax |author= Goldacre B |work=The Guardian |date=30 August 2008 |accessdate=2008-08-30 |url=https://www.theguardian.com/society/2008/aug/30/mmr.health.media|archiveurl=http://www.badscience.net/2008/08/the-medias-mmr-hoax/|archivedate=30 August 2008 | location=London}}</ref> By the time that scientists had shown the narrative to be false, it had become part of the folk epidemiology of autism.<ref name="1."/><ref name="3.">{{cite journal|last1=Taylor|first1=B.|title=Vaccines and the changing epidemiology of autism|journal=Child: Care, Health and Development|volume=32|issue=5|year=2006|pages=511–519|issn=0305-1862|doi=10.1111/j.1365-2214.2006.00655.x}}</ref> The narrative was easy to understand and apparently consistent with anecdotal evidence of children receiving autism diagnoses shortly after having been vaccinated. Doctors were highly critical of the media coverage for triggering a decline in vaccination rates.<ref>{{cite news|url=http://news.bbc.co.uk/2/hi/health/5118166.stm|title= Doctors issue plea over MMR jab|work=BBC News|accessdate=2009-02-04 | date=26 June 2006}}</ref> The false belief has persisted despite a public information campaign aimed at making parents aware that by refusing vaccinations they are putting their children at risk of contracting infectious diseases that are frequently fatal.<ref name=MMRthefacts/>
===Mass media=== Observers have criticized the involvement of mass media in the controversy alleging that the media provided Wakefield's study with more credibility than it deserved.<ref name=EMBOreports>{{cite journal | author = Moore Andrew | year = 2006 | title = Bad science in the headlines: Who takes responsibility when science is distorted in the mass media? | url = http://www.nature.com/embor/journal/v7/n12/full/7400862.html | journal = [[EMBO Reports]] | volume = 7 | issue = 12| pages = 1193–1196 | doi = 10.1038/sj.embor.7400862 | pmc = 1794697 }}</ref> Endorsements by [[celebrity|celebrities]] such as [[Jenny McCarthy]] and [[Robert F. Kennedy Jr.]] were highly publicized.<ref name="5.">Wallace, A. An Epidemic of Fear: How Panicked Parents Skipping Shots Endangers Us All. ''[[Wired (magazine)|Wired]]''. [Online] 2009, Nov. [https://www.wired.com/magazine/2009/10/ff_waronscience/all/1]</ref> Later commentary faulted the coverage for giving a misleading impression of the degree to which the evidence supported a link between the MMR vaccine and autism.<ref name=hilton>{{cite journal | author = Hilton S, Petticrew M, Hunt K | year = 2007 | title = Parents' champions vs. vested interests: Who do parents believe about MMR? A qualitative study | journal = [[BMC Public Health]] | volume = 7 | issue = | page = 42 | pmc=1851707 | pmid=17391507 | doi=10.1186/1471-2458-7-42}}</ref><ref name=Speers>{{cite journal |vauthors=Speers T, Justin L |title= Journalists and jabs: media coverage of the MMR vaccine |journal= Communication and Medicine |volume= 1 |issue= 2 |pages= 171–181 |doi= 10.1515/come.2004.1.2.171 |pmid= 16808699 |date=September 2004}}</ref><ref name=Jacson>{{cite journal | author = Jackson T | year = 2003 | title = MMR: more scrutiny, please | url = http://www.bmj.com/content/326/7401/1272.1.extract?sid=82a788eb-c6ad-4ae7-8087-1d4ba89867b6 | journal = [[The BMJ]] | volume = 326 | issue = 7401| page = 1272 | doi=10.1136/bmj.326.7401.1272}}</ref><ref name=Dobson>{{cite journal | author = Dobson Roger |date=May 2003 | title = Media misled the public over the MMR vaccine, study says | journal = The BMJ | volume = 326 | issue = 7399| page = 1107 | doi = 10.1136/bmj.326.7399.1107-a | pmc=1150987 | pmid=12763972}}</ref>
===Consequences=== The scientific consensus is that the MMR vaccine has no link to the development of autism, and that the vaccine's benefits greatly outweigh its risks.<ref name=MMRthefacts/> The false belief that the [[MMR vaccine]] causes autism led to a sharp drop in rates of vaccination in the UK and Ireland after 1998, creating a major public health risk. Lower vaccination rates were followed by increases in the incidence of measles and mumps, and the resulting cases of permanent disability and death.<ref name=McIntyre/>
Public fears about vaccination have consumed resources that might otherwise have advanced research into the real causes of autism.<ref name="5."/> There have been thirteen studies that properly followed the [[scientific method]] and contained large numbers of participants that failed to connect autism to the [[MMR vaccine]].<ref name="4.">{{cite journal|last1=Gerber|first1=Jeffrey S.|last2=Offit|first2=Paul A.|title=Vaccines and Autism: A Tale of Shifting Hypotheses|journal=Clinical Infectious Diseases|volume=48|issue=4|year=2009|pages=456–461|issn=1058-4838|doi=10.1086/596476|pmc=2908388}}</ref> There have been seven well-constructed studies that have attempted to link autism to [[thiomersal]] in vaccines and were unsuccessful.<ref name="4."/> Special interest groups continue to push for more research on the link between vaccines and autism.<ref name="4."/><ref name="5."/> Further research motivated by the folk epidemiology of autism would represent a lost opportunity to investigate autism's true causes.<ref name="5."/>
==See also== *[[Medical model of autism]] *[[Controversies in autism]] *[[Vaccine controversy]] *[[Epidemiology of autism]] *[[Thiomersal controversy]] *[[MMR vaccine controversy]] *''[[Autism's False Prophets]]'' *[[Measles outbreaks in the 21st century]] *[[Autism Speaks]] *[[Autism rights movement]] *[[Autism therapies]]
